An American Girl Among Hostages Released on Sunday, Biden Says

President Biden on Sunday hailed on Sunday the release of Avigail Idan, a 4-year-old U.S. citizen who Hamas held for seven weeks, and vowed to keep working to secure freedom for others in captivity and extend the pause in the fighting.

Avigail, whose name has sometimes been rendered as ‚ÄúAbigail‚Äù in the U.S. news media, is a dual U.S. and Israeli citizen and was seized during the Hamas terrorist attack on Oct. 7 after her parents were killed. Her case had been the focus of widespread international attention and concern as she turned 4 on Friday. She was among the 17 hostages released on Sunday, and Biden said she was ‚Äúsafely in Israel.‚Äù

Workers in sex-related industries ‚Äî whether in a brothel, a strip club or online ‚Äî often risk their safety and face social and employment discrimination. But a lesser-known struggle is that it‚Äôs often difficult for sex workers to maintain a basic bank account and other financial relationships that most people take for granted, even when their work is legal.

Banks are shutting down what appears to be an increasing number of customer accounts, usually with little explanation, throwing their customers‚Äô lives into chaos. The closures have hit small-business owners who routinely deposit cash; individuals who withdrew larger sums than usual; and others who unknowingly transacted with suspected fraudsters, The New York Times has found. 

Without bank accounts, people are unable to accomplish the most basic financial tasks: collecting, spending and saving their earnings. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the financial challenges sex workers face. Photos by @carly.zavala and Niki Chan Wylie for The New York Times

For a desert city, Dubai appears like a water wonderland. To maintain its opulence, the city relies on freshwater it doesn‚Äôt have, turning to the sea and spending billions on energy-intensive desalination technologies that help hydrate a rapidly growing metropolis. Experts say Dubai‚Äôs reliance on desalination is damaging the Persian Gulf.

Dubai, the most populous city in the United Arab Emirates, has taken steps to address the damage of desalination with environmental initiatives and new technology, but pressure is building to do more. Later this month, the city will host the United Nations global climate summit, known as COP28, an event that has already increased tensions because of fossil fuel investments by the UAE and other participating countries.

Read more about the hefty cost of the city‚Äôs water world. Photos by @katarinapremfors

Paju, a satellite city 22 miles northeast of Seoul, is an intentional and euphoric celebration of books and the bookmaking process.

Paju is home to the nation‚Äôs elaborate book publishing hub ‚Äî officially known as Paju Publishing Culture, Information and National Industrial Park but commonly referred to as Paju Book City. The city houses around 900 book-related businesses, including printing presses, distribution companies and design studios.

The book city‚Äôs mission ‚Äî to ‚Äúactively support culture and arts based on books‚Äù ‚Äî can be seen in buildings all over town. At the core of Paju Book City is the Asia Publication Culture and Information Center, a six-story complex that includes an education facility, an events hall and an exhibition space, and that serves as a social and professional nucleus for local publishers. The center draws almost 10,000 visitors a year. Every fall, it hosts a book festival, bringing together local authors, artists and book lovers.

Just off Australia‚Äôs largest container port lies a neighborhood with a scent so distinctive that passing taxi drivers will sometimes roll down their windows for a whiff of the rich and unmistakably beery aroma.

That smell, officially recognized by the City of Melbourne last year for its ‚Äúintangible cultural heritage,‚Äù emanates from a brick factory on a corner lot in an industrial district known as Port Melbourne. Every vessel of Vegemite, the spread beloved in Australia and not so much outside it, has begun its journey here for the past 80 years.

The brand celebrated its 100th birthday this year, but what does the ‚Äúconcentrated yeast extract‚Äù on the label mean? Have you tried @vegemite? Tap the link in our bio to read the full story. Photos by @abivar

Moderated by Emily Bazelon, a staff writer for The New York Times Magazine, we assembled a panel of seven scholars and experts ‚Äî three Palestinian, three Israeli and an American ‚Äî to discuss the history of the Oslo peace process, which was the first direct dialogue between Israel and the P.L.O. and would become their most sustained effort to reach a settlement. Named for the city where the secret meetings took place, the Oslo talks ran through most of the 1990s and came as close as any negotiated process ever has to resolving this intractable conflict.

But in the end, Oslo failed. The reasons for that failure ‚Äî and the lessons it has to teach us ‚Äî have been debated ever since. Was it a genuine chance for peace? Was it doomed from the start? These photos show some of the pivotal moments on the road to and from Oslo. To read the complete discussion, go to the link in our bio.

Hundreds of thousands of Moroccans are still estimated to be living in tents in the devastated villages of the Atlas Mountains, where a powerful earthquake on Sept. 8 killed about 3,000 people. Recent rains and flooding have further exposed residents to vulnerable living conditions as they wait for officials to act.

The government has pledged to spend about $11.8 billion to rebuild and repair the homes of an estimated 4.2 million Moroccans in the next five years. But officials are also weighing how best to restore the cultural heritage of a region that is an important part of the country‚Äôs tourism industry. Tap the link in our bio to read the full story. But like hundreds of deceased NFL players ‚Äî including the Pro Football Hall of Famers Mike Webster, Junior Seau and Ken Stabler ‚Äî they, too, had CTE, the degenerative brain disease linked to repeated hits to the head. For now, CTE can be positively diagnosed only posthumously. The brains of 152 young athletes, both men and women who died before turning 30, were studied by researchers at Boston University.

As the attractions in Oaxaca multiply and tourists pack its new hotels and upscale restaurants, the city in southern Mexico has still preserved its character. 

Oaxacans are constantly innovating, reworking their traditional cuisine or adapting their ancient textile heritage. The city‚Äôs arts scene draws young people, giving Oaxaca a vigor that similar small cities would envy.

The city hosts festivals year round, but it‚Äôs especially joyous in December, when residents honor Mexico‚Äôs patron saint, the Virgin of Guadalupe, and the city‚Äôs patron saint, Our Lady of Solitude.

Some two dozen hostages held in Gaza, including Israelis and Thai nationals, were released from captivity on Friday, Egyptian and Qatari officials said, and Israel confirmed it had freed 39 Palestinian prisoners and detainees, completing the first exchange laid out by a deal between Israel and Hamas for a temporary cease-fire.

The hostages were initially transferred to Egypt before being returned to Israel. Israeli officials released the names of the 13 freed Israeli hostages, all women and children. Four were young children and most of the nine women were over age 70.

After earlier statements that 12 Thais were also freed, the governments of Qatar and Egypt ‚Äî which were involved in mediating the cease-fire deal ‚Äî said the count was actually 10 Thais and one Filipino.

The start of the four-day truce brought a measure of hope for families missing loved ones, a brief reprieve for Gazans battered by seven weeks of war and a faint sense of optimism for a change in the trajectory of the conflict. Israel and Hamas have said they would abide by the deal, but past truces between the sides have often fallen apart, and both have signaled that they would continue fighting when the pause expires.

This caption has been edited to reflect statements from Qatar and Egypt on the number of Thai nationals released. This is a developing story. Read more live updates at the link in our bio.

For many New Yorkers, the city‚Äôs subways are the performance spaces they encounter most often. Every day, dancers and musicians put on a subterranean show, using mass transit as a stage.

About 850,000 older Americans reside in assisted-living facilities, which have become one of the most lucrative branches of the long-term care industry catering to people 65 and older. Investors, regional companies and international real estate trusts have jumped into the industry to make a profit. These facilities often charge $5,000 a month or more, charging extra to help residents get to the shower, bathroom or dining room; to deliver meals to their rooms; to have staff check-in for daily ‚Äúreassurance‚Äù or simply to remind residents when it‚Äôs time to eat or take their medications. 

Assisted-living costs are so crushingly high that most Americans can‚Äôt afford them. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the financial cost of long-term care. Photos by @arianadrehsler and @ackermangruber

No Sign of Terrorism in Vehicle Explosion at U.S.-Canada Bridge, Hochul Says

Two people died Wednesday when a car hit a median, went airborne and exploded on the American side of a bridge near Niagara Falls between Canada and the United States, prompting border closings and upending travel plans on the eve of the Thanksgiving holiday.

No explosive devices were found, and Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York said an initial investigation had found no evidence that the crash at the Niagara Falls International Rainbow Bridge was related to terrorism. The driver was traveling at an ‚Äúextraordinarily high rate of speed‚Äù before the car crashed into a median and flew over an eight-foot fence, the governor said.

Some of the most hurricane-prone regions of the U.S. lie on the Carolina coast. 

Between 2016 and 2022, the Carolinas were hit by five hurricanes: Matthew, Florence, Dorian, Isaias and Ian.

At the crossroads of these hurricanes lie the metro areas of Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, and Wilmington, North Carolina. These two metros, known for their striking coastlines, have been regularly battered by hurricanes this century.

Behind 94 Acts of Shocking Violence, Years of Glaring Mistakes

Amid a drumbeat of incidents involving homeless, mentally ill people, officials in New York said they were doing their best. The reality is different, a New York Times investigation has found.

Times reporters spent more than a year examining how often homeless, mentally ill people under the care of the city have committed acts of violence. There is no official accounting of such incidents, but The Times set out to create its own, scouring court filings, police records and news reports to identify more than 130 acts of violence carried out in recent years by people who were homeless and mentally ill.

The reporters scrutinized each case, conducting more than 250 interviews; obtaining tens of thousands of pages of confidential treatment records; and visiting courthouses, jails, prisons and psychiatric wards. The lack of public information about the incidents made it impossible to draw conclusions about a quarter of the cases. Still, the examination identified 94 instances in the past decade in which breakdowns of the city‚Äôs social safety net preceded the violence, sometimes by just days or hours.

Read the full investigation at the link in our bio. Video by Amy Julia Harris, Jan Ransom, Rebecca Suner and Ruru Kuo.

Visitors normally flock to Death Valley National Park to feel the searing heat and take in the barren landscape. This fall, they‚Äôve been drawn by a different natural feature: water.

On Aug. 20, during a deluge from Tropical Storm Hilary, the park recorded 2.2 inches of rain ‚Äî more than a year‚Äôs worth and the most that had ever fallen in a single day in Death Valley. Afterward, the park had its longest closure ever ‚Äî lasting nearly two months. 

When Death Valley reopened this fall, visitors were greeted by a miraculous sight: A vast lake appeared almost overnight in the white salt flats of Badwater Basin. It was the first time a lake had formed here in nearly 20 years.

Twenty-eight premature babies who had been in intensive care at the embattled Al-Shifa Hospital in northern Gaza were transported across the border to Egypt for medical care on Monday, according to the United Nations and an Egyptian state television network, Al Qahera News. The rule was unspoken, but the Israeli and Palestinian teenagers in the Greater Jerusalem swim club had abided by it forever without even thinking: No politics in the pool.

Premature Babies Are Treated After Evacuation From Al-Shifa Hospital

Thirty-one premature babies in extremely critical condition were evacuated from the embattled Al-Shifa Hospital in northern Gaza on Sunday and taken to another hospital in the enclave‚Äôs south, the Palestine Red Crescent Society and the World Health Organization said on social media.
Emergency medical workers from the Red Crescent and the W.H.O., a United Nations agency, took the infants by ambulance to Al-Helal Emirati Maternity Hospital in Rafah, where they were receiving urgent care.

It said that the babies had been moved in temperature-controlled incubators to Al-Helal, where they were being stabilized and cared for in the hospital‚Äôs neonatal intensive care unit.

Officials in Gaza and Egypt have said the babies will be transported over the border to Egypt for treatment, though the timing was unclear. On Sunday, Gaza‚Äôs health ministry published a list of the 31 infant evacuees and issued a call for their families to go to the hospital to identify them, adding that the parents might be able to join the babies in Egypt. Rosalynn Carter, a true life partner to former President Jimmy Carter who helped propel him from rural Georgia to the White House in a single decade and became the most politically active first lady since Eleanor Roosevelt, died on Sunday in Plains, Georgia. She was 96.

When Sally Abed and Alon-Lee Green flew from Israel to New York last week, they found a version of the U.S. they‚Äôd never seen before: one split by the conflict between Palestinians and Israelis.

Instead, in New York, Washington and Boston, they found packed auditoriums and eager audiences in community centers, synagogues, libraries and the offices of politicians like Bernie Sanders and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.
